title: 114_hr6175
content: Section 212(a)(3)(B)(i) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include inadmissibility of aliens identified in the terrorist screening database. Additionally, Section 2 addresses the deportability of aliens identified in the same database. Section 2 amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to specify that aliens lawfully admitted for permanent residence are not deportable for being identified in the terrorist screening database. Section 3 addresses waivers of inadmissibility for aliens in the same database. Section 212(d)(3) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow the Secretary of Homeland Security to grant nonimmigrant visas on a case-by-case basis for national security interests. The Secretary of Homeland Security can grant waivers for nonimmigrant visas for national security reasons with the unanimous agreement of key officials. SEC. 4. UNAVAILABILITY OF CERTAIN IMMIGRATION BENEFITS TO ALIENS IDENTIFIED IN TERRORIST SCREENING DATABASE. Amendments are made to various sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding asylum, withholding of removal, and cancellation of removal for certain permanent and nonpermanent residents. Notable changes include adding new categories for inadmissibility and deportability under specific sections. Amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act include changes to cancellation of removal for certain nonpermanent residents, voluntary departure eligibility, and new categories for inadmissibility and deportability. Amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act include changes to voluntary departure eligibility for aliens found inadmissible or deportable under specific sections. Amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act involve changes to eligibility for voluntary departure for aliens found inadmissible or deportable under specific sections. Additionally, the Secretary of Homeland Security is required to revise regulations implementing the United Nations Convention Against Torture within 120 days of the Act's enactment. The revised regulations under title 8, Code of Federal Regulations, exclude certain aliens from protection and make them ineligible for withholding or deferral of removal. They also allow for reopening and readjudication of past determinations, applying to acts and conditions regardless of when they occurred. SEC. 5. EXPEDITED REMOVAL OF ALIENS INADMISSIBLE OR DEPORTABLE ON SECURITY AND RELATED GROUNDS. Section 238 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow for the removal of aliens who are not permanent residents and are inadmissible or deportable on security or related grounds. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the authority to determine inadmissibility or deportability and issue an order of removal. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows for the removal of aliens who are inadmissible or deportable on security grounds. The Secretary of Homeland Security can determine inadmissibility or deportability and issue removal orders. Aliens who fall under section 237(a)(4)(B) can be issued a removal order if they have not been granted a waiver under section 212(d)(3)(C) and were not lawfully admitted for permanent residence or had conditional permanent resident status. The Secretary of Homeland Security will conduct expedited proceedings according to regulations. The Secretary of Homeland Security will conduct expedited proceedings for aliens under section 237(a)(4)(B) according to regulations. The proceedings include providing the alien with notice of charges, the right to representation, the opportunity to inspect evidence, verification of identity, and maintaining a record for judicial review. The Secretary of Homeland Security conducts expedited proceedings for aliens under section 237(a)(4)(B) with notice of charges, right to representation, evidence inspection, identity verification, and judicial review. The final order of removal must not be adjudicated by the same person who issues the charges, and judicial review must be allowed within 14 days of the order. Aliens adjudicated inadmissible or deportable are ineligible for discretionary relief from removal. The Act and its amendments will be effective upon enactment and will apply to all aliens in the terrorist screening database from that date onwards.
